Key Match Events: Fakhar Zaman and captain Babar Azam starred as Pakistan pulled off a dramatic, rain-hit 21-run victory over New Zealand
Rachin Ravindra smashed his third ton of the World Cup while a fit-again Kane Williamson made up for lost time with a 95
Fakhar Zaman took the attack to the New Zealand bowlers, smashing four sixes and as many boundaries in his 39-ball fifty
Zaman completed his 11th ODI hundred, and first in a World Cup, with a six and a single off Mitchell Santner
Pre-Game Insights: Pakistan and New Zealand both have eight points and remain in contention for semifinal spots with a match each left to play in the group stage
India and South Africa have already wrapped up two of the semifinal places. That has left Australia, New Zealand, Pakistan and Afghanistan in the race for the final two spots
Post-Match Reflections: Pakistan skipper Babar was in good spirits after the match, saying, 'When we came into the dressing room [after the first innings], we passed on the message that we needed one good partnership. I told Fakhar that he needs to bat till the end, so all credit to Fakhar'
Williamson was magnanimous in defeat, saying, 'The ground wasn’t big enough for Fakhar, and he played an exceptional knock. [We] just need to take the positives into the next match'
Miscellaneous Highlights: Hasan Ali, who replaced Usama Mir to give the 1992 champions an extra pace option, had Conway caught behind for 35 to end the pair’s 68-run stand and bring Williamson to the wicket

Playing his first match since sustaining a fractured thumb against Bangladesh last month, Williamson toyed with the bowlers and provided the perfect foil to Ravindra before cutting loose, having made his second half-century of the tournament

Ravindra, who was born in Wellington to Indian parents from Bengaluru, delighted the local fans with measured stroke play and provided moments of magic to go past 500 runs in the World Cup with a 94-ball 108 that included 15 fours and a six
Others: Pakistan now have eight points from as many games with their last match against England in Kolkata on November 11
They not only need to win that but also hope New Zealand lose to Sri Lanka on Thursday in Bengaluru at this same venue or the match is hit by rain
New Zealand posted a commanding 401-6 from 50 overs
Zaman’s century came off 63 balls with nine sixes and six boundaries
